High Pollen:
 

FAQs

What is pollen?

Pollen is a fine, powdery substance released by anthers, a part of the flower. Pollen grains contain the male gametes of plants. Sperm cells are the nearest human equivalent to pollen.

Why is there pollen in the air?

Because plants are immobile, they cannot go searching for mates the way that animals can. Plants have instead developed other ways of distributing their pollen to ensure their male gametes (contained in pollen grains) reach a receptive female. Some plant types use the wind to carry pollen between plants. These plants have very simple, dry flowers that do not secrete nectar to attract birds and insects. Wind-borne pollen can drift considerable distances. Pine pollen grains, for instance, have wings that serve as floats enabling them to be carried hundreds of kilometers. Plant with wind-borne pollen also produce a LOT of pollen because the chance it will reach a receptive female plant is very low. It is wind-borne pollen that is in the air and is responsible for seasonal allergies.

By contrast, the flowers of plants that use insects and birds to carry pollen between individuals generally have features to attract pollinators such as colour, scent or a sugary nectar. The pollen these plants produce is generally larger than wind-borne pollen and has features on its surface that help it get snagged in hairs and feathers. The pollen is also heavier than wind-borne pollen grains, making it less able to drift on the wind. Plants that use pollinators to distribute their pollen also produce less pollen than those with wind-borne pollen. Pollen from plants that use pollinators is generally a low allergy risk because the levels in the air are low.

Why is pollen a problem?

Pollen cannot cause disease in the way that bacteria and viruses can. Instead, people can develop allergies to the pollen of certain plants and have symptoms when that pollen is around in the environment. That is, for these people a particular type of pollen is an allergy trigger.

Whole pollen grains landing in the eyes or nasal passages can trigger rhinitis or hay fever, characterized by a blocked or runny nose, sneezing and itchy eyes. Around 18% of Australians have hay fever.

Pollen can also fragment into bits small enough to enter the lungs and trigger asthma in a sensitive person. Asthma causes a narrowing of the airways making it harder to breathe. Around 1 in 9 Australians has asthma.

Why forecast pollen?

Forecasting the level of pollen in Victoria's air helps inform people with respiratory conditions like asthma and hay fever of days when the outdoor levels of their trigger pollen are high enough to cause symptoms. This information allows them to take preventative measures such as staying indoors or having their medication close at hand.

What is thunderstorm asthma?

Every year during Victoria’s grass pollen season (October through December) there is a seasonal increase in asthma and hay fever symptoms. There is also a small chance of a thunderstorm asthma event. Thunderstorm asthma is thought to be triggered by a unique combination of high grass pollen levels and a certain type of thunderstorm, causing many people to develop asthma symptoms over a short period of time. The sudden onset and large increase in asthma symptoms following a storm is described as thunderstorm asthma. For more information about thunderstorm asthma, visit the Victorian Department of Health website (health.vic.gov.au).

How are pollen counts done?

There’s a video showing how we do pollen counting here.

We use an air-sampling device called a Burkard spore trap to capture airborne pollen on a glass slide, which we stain with a dye and count using a microscope. During the pollen season, a slide is removed from the trap at the same time each day and counted to identify the different types of pollen that are on it based on their distinctive shapes. The pollen level is a report of the average concentration of each kind of pollen caught in the trap in the previous 24 hours. We use this information to help generate our pollen forecasts for the days ahead.

Pollen count definitions

To aid interpretation, the average number of grass pollen grains per cubic meter of air is classified into LOW, MODERATE, HIGH and EXTREME. For grass pollen, the classification is as shown in the following table:

Number of Grass Pollen Grains

   

Classification

0 to 19
   
LOW
20 to 49
   
MODERATE
50 to 99
   
HIGH
≥ 100
   
EXTREME

We expect most grass-sensitive people will experience symptoms on days with HIGH grass pollen levels. For other pollen types and for mould spores, we don’t yet know the levels that cause symptoms and have simply divided the expected range of daily concentrations up. In future, we will use survey scores submitted through the app to help us identify where we should draw the HIGH cut-off for each pollen type. That’s one reason why every survey score you submit helps us better understand what’s causing hay fever.

What factors affect the daily pollen count?

Several factors affect the daily pollen count, including fluctuations in temperature, wind conditions, humidity and precipitation, and of course the biology of the plants themselves.

Taking grass as an example, in Victoria the grasses flower mostly in late spring and early summer. During the flowering season, weather conditions such as wind and humidity will also affect how much grass pollen is in the air. Melbourne's worst grass pollen days are in November, when hot northerly winds bring pollen into the city from pastures in the surrounding countryside. Southerly winds, by contrast, are cooler and more humid and bring mainly pollen-free air into Melbourne from the ocean.

Why don't you forecast more pollen types?

We'd love to. But the funding we get from the Victorian Government is to do with the thunderstorm asthma forecasting service and supports our grass pollen counting and forecasting across the state from October 1 to December 31. Because a longer counting season and more forecasts costs money, we’re looking at ways we can fund this extension to our service. One thing we’re trying in 2021 is a subscription service. Grass pollen forecasts, as always, are free, with other pollen forecasts available through the Melbourne Pollen app on a subscription basis. If you want more information, why not give it a try?

Is the pollen season the same from year to year?

Not exactly. The beginning and end of the pollen season and its severity (how much pollen is produced) will depend on weather, mainly rainfall, over the previous months or even years. For instance, rainfall over winter and spring determines how much grass will grow (and hence how much pollen will be produced) and current weather (wind direction and temperature) determines how much of this grass pollen will be transported from rural areas to the places where people live.

Why does Melbourne Pollen feature grass pollen so heavily?

We focus on grass pollen because in Victoria, grass pollen is the main cause of outdoor allergies. Grass pollen triggers most of the hay fever from October to December and is also responsible for the seasonal increase in asthma. Outbreaks of thunderstorm asthma are also associated with high grass pollen levels.

How many pollen-counting stations are there in Victoria?

Before 2017 there were three pollen traps operating in Victoria - Parkville, Burwood and Waurn Ponds near Geelong. In 2017, the Victorian government provided additional investment to expand the pollen monitoring network by adding five pollen traps at the following locations:

  • Hamilton
  • Creswick (near Ballarat)
  • Bendigo
  • Dookie (near Shepparton)
  • Churchill (near Morwell)

The eight pollen traps across Victoria (the VicTAPS network) are supporting the verification and refinement of the thunderstorm asthma forecasting model during the grass pollen season, by providing a more detailed understanding of grass pollen levels and the movement of grass pollen across the state.

Can you recommend any medication for my allergies?

We do not offer medical advice. Please consult your doctor to discuss proper treatment of your allergy symptoms.

 

Manage Your Subscription

Who made this app?

This App is the property of the University of Melbourne. Pollen count data are provided by The School of BioSciences, University of Melbourne and Deakin AIRwatch, Deakin University. Air Quality data is provided by EPA Victoria is licensed under CC BY 4.0

div10:
Help us help you.

We are researchers at the University of Melbourne. Your subscription helps support the service, and in return you get:

Additional Allergen Forecasts

New forecasts for mould spores and tree and weed pollen.

Additional Allergen Forecasts

Our state-of-the-art Machine Learning Models use real pollen and mould spore count data to predict the levels of these allergens in the air.

Grass
Grass
Mould
Alternaria
Tree
Cypress
Myrtle
Olive
Plane
Weed
Plantain
 

Longer Range Forecasts

Up to 10 days of forecasts so you can plan the week ahead.

Longer Range Forecasts

Our state-of-the-art Machine Learning Models use satellite data provided by NASA and weather forecast data from the Bureau of Meteorology to forecasting pollen and mould levels in the air up to 10 days in advance.

 

Historical Forecast Data

Up to 100 days of historical data for you to track patterns

Historical Forecast Data

By clicking on the ”Data” tab, our supporters can see up to 100 days of historical forecast data for mould spores as well as tree, weed and grass pollen.

More Air Quality Data

Current air quality data from a range of EPA monitoring sites around Victoria.

More Air Quality Data

The quality of the air we breath makes a big difference to how we feel and our health. In Victoria, the Environmental Protection Authority monitors the air at various locations using “standard” and “sensor” monitoring equipment. Our subscribers can see all available information at these sites.

Example of data available from a “standard” EPA site:

Your subscription will renew automatically unless the auto renew function is turned off at least 24 hours before the end of the current subscription period. You can manage your subscription and turn off the “auto renewal” function in your account settings at any time after purchase. Payment will be charged to your Account upon confirmation of your purchase. In some instances, the Service may offer you a “free trial period”. Canceling the trial period will immediately disable your subscription. Any unused portion of a free trial period (if offered) is forfeited by you if you purchase any subscription to the Service. All subscription purchases are NON REFUNDABLE to the fullest extent permitted by law. By subscribing you confirm that you have read the EULA and the Privacy Policy and agree to be bound by their terms.


Cypress pollen

Cypress pollen comes from members of the large family of conifers or cone-bearing trees and shrubs called the Cupressaceae or cypresses. Pencil pines are a familiar type of cypress. While they don’t have flowers as such, cypresses still produce pollen - lots of pollen! In fact, cypress pollen is Victoria’s most abundant airborne pollen type. There are both native and non-native cypresses in Australia, and cypress pollen is present in Victoria’s air from July through to December.

 

Why should I care?

Cypress pollen is the main cause of hayfever in Japan. Although the types of cypress that cause hayfever in Japan are not widely grown here in Australia, a native cypress called Callitris also produces allergenic pollen. Associations between cypress pollen levels in the air and hayfever symptoms have been reported both here in Australia and in Europe. While more evidence is needed, looking for associations between cypress pollen and hayfever in Victoria is one of ways we’ll be using the symptom scores reported through the app.

Months in flower

 

Myrtle pollen

Myrtle pollen comes from members of the Myrtaceae or myrtles, a family that includes some of Australia’s most iconic plants. Think eucalypts, bottlebrushes, paperbarks, the list goes on. The Myrtaceae are not surprisingly everywhere, in gardens, urban parks and of course the eucalypt forests that cover large parts of Australia. While their showy flowers and nectar mean these plants aren’t wind-pollinated but instead use birds and bees as pollinators to disperse their pollen, the sheer number of myrtle flowers means that at certain times of the year there’s lots of myrtle pollen in the air. Myrtle pollen is in Victoria’s air from September through to March.

 

Why should I care?

While there’s not much currently linking myrtle pollen to allergies, that’s because very few studies have been done. However, those studies that have been done found associations between myrtle pollen levels and hayfever symptoms, and between eucalypt pollen and childhood asthma. More evidence is needed, and seeing if there’s an association between myrtle pollen and hayfever in Victoria is one of ways we’ll be using the symptom scores reported through the app.

Months in flower

 

Olive pollen

Olive pollen is produced by members of the Oleaceae or olives, a family of trees, shrubs and vines. Although the word olive suggests plants with a Mediterranean origin, there are olives that are native to Australia - in fact, there’s even a native olive! But most of the olive pollen we encounter does come from non-native plants such as olive itself, ash trees, jasmine vine and privet. Jasmine, of course, has flowers that are strongly scented, especially on a warm summer evening. Scented flowers are typically pollinated by insects. But most plants in the olive family are wind-pollinated and have unobtrusive flowers that don’t attract pollinators. Olive pollen is in Victoria’s air in September and October.

 

Why should I care?

The pollen of olive and ash (Fraxinus) is highly allergenic. Pollen from olive orchards is a major cause of respiratory allergies in southern Europe, and pollen from common ash (Fraxinus excelsior) causes allergies in northern and central Europe. Because the allergens present in olive and ash pollen are similar, people with an allergy to olive pollen also react to ash pollen and vice versa.

Months in flower

 

Plane tree pollen

Generally, when we describe a pollen type, we refer to it as coming from a family or genus of plants. But with plane tree pollen the pollen comes from a single type of tree, the hybrid London plane (Platanus × acerifolia). London plane trees are ideally suited to urban environments because they are quick growing, have an excellent shady canopy during the heat of summer and are tolerant of warm weather and pollution. London planes dominate the streetscapes of cities and towns around the world, including in Australia. Plane tree pollen is in Victoria’s air during September and October.

 

Why should I care?

Despite the numerous services they provide in urban areas, few trees are more despised than the London plane. Plane trees are wind-pollinated, and their pollen is allergenic and a known cause of hayfever in Europe. In Australia, less is known about the relationship between plane tree pollen and hayfever although one study from Sydney found that only a quarter of people who blamed plane trees for their hayfever were allergic to plane tree pollen. In addition to allergenic pollen, plane tree fruits and leaves also release small hairs into the air. It is possible these hairs are responsible for reported hayfever symptoms because they can irritate the eye and nose. We’ll be checking for associations between plane tree pollen and hayfever using the symptom scores reported through the app.

Months in flower

 

Alternaria

Alternaria is not a type of pollen and doesn’t come from a plant. Alternaria is instead a type of fungus or mould that typically grows on dead plant matter although some types are disease-causing. Alternaria occurs almost everywhere and is a natural part of the environment. The club-shaped spores of Alternaria are multi-cellular and dispersed by the wind. Alternaria spores are in Victoria’s air from October to January.

 

Why should I care?

Alternaria spores are allergenic and a known trigger of hayfever and asthma, including severe asthma. Studies overseas point to a role for Alternaria in outbreaks of thunderstorm asthma.

Months present in the air

 
Image of Alternaria spores Abdulghafour, CC BY-SA 4.0 , via Wikimedia Commons
 

Plantain pollen

Plantain pollen comes from members of the Plantago or plantain genus. There are both native and introduced plantains, but most plantain pollen comes from several types of weedy plantains that are a common feature of lawns and urban parks. These plants share the same common name as a cooking banana but are unrelated to it. Plantain pollen is in Victoria’s air from October to January.

 

Why should I care?

Plantain pollen is allergenic and a known trigger of hayfever in Europe. However, because its association with hayfever in Australia is unknown, we’ll be checking for associations between plantain pollen and hayfever using the symptom scores reported through the app.

Months in flower

 

Grass pollen

Grass pollen comes from members of the Poaceae or grass family. Grasses are a large and diverse family and grass-based ecosystems (savannahs, prairies and so on) dominate large parts of the earth’s surface. Grasses are also important sources of food, with three cereals - wheat, rice and maize - providing almost half of the energy we eat. Grasses are the main food consumed by grazing animals such as cows and sheep. Grass pollen is in Victoria’s air from October to December.

 

More Information

Grass pollen is allergenic and a known trigger of hayfever and asthma, including severe asthma. Grass pollen is associated with outbreaks of thunderstorm asthma in Victoria.

Months in flower

 

What is PM2.5?

PM refers to particulate matter, the mixture of solid particles and liquid droplets present in the air. Here, 2.5 refers to the size of these particles, which are smaller than 2.5 micrometers (µm) in diameter (i.e., smaller than 0.0025 mm). The PM2.5 reading is the total mass (in micrograms) of 2.5 µm particles per cubic meter of air and is written as µg/m3

Where does it come from?

There are both natural and man-made sources of PM2.5, with a common source in urban areas being car and truck exhausts. Other sources are smoke from bush fires and wood heaters, and emissions from industry.

How does it affect our health?

Most of the adverse health effects of air pollution are associated with PM2.5 exposure. Because they are so small, PM2.5 particles can penetrate deep into the lungs and in some cases even enter the bloodstream. Health effects can occur after both short and long-term exposure. Short-term PM2.5 exposure is associated with poorer health in people with heart or lung conditions. High PM2.5 levels can trigger asthma and bronchitis, for example.

What is PM10?

PM refers to particulate matter, the mixture of solid particles and liquid droplets present in the air. Here, 10 refers to the size of these particles, which are smaller than 10 micrometers (µm) in diameter (i.e., smaller than 0.001 mm). The PM10 reading is the total mass (in micrograms) of 10 µm particles per cubic meter of air and is written as µg/m3. Note that the PM10 reading includes PM2.5 as well.

Where does it come from?

There are both natural and man-made sources of PM10. These include car and truck exhaust and smoke from bush fires, but also windblown or ‘raised’ dust from construction sites, unsealed roads and bare fields.

How does it affect our health?

The larger PM10 particles can penetrate the upper parts of the respiratory system, and the smaller particles (PM2.5) can enter deep into the lungs. Health effects can occur after both short and long-term exposure. Symptoms of short-term exposure can include nose and throat irritation, and worse asthma and bronchitis. People with pre-existing respiratory or cardiac conditions might also experience worse symptoms when PM10 levels are high. Exposure can cause heart attacks and an irregular heartbeat in people with a cardiac condition, for example.

What is CO?

CO is the chemical name for carbon monoxide, a colorless and odorless gas.

Where does it come from?

CO is produced when something is burned. Common source in urban areas are car and truck exhausts and gas household heaters.

How does it affect our health?

CO enters the blood stream and reduces the amount of oxygen available for organs like the heart and brain to use. Exposure to high CO levels outdoors is unlikely but it is possible for the gas to accumulate in confined spaces, such as in your home. Symptoms of high CO exposure include dizziness, nausea and unconsciousness.

What is O3?

O3 is the chemical name for ozone, a naturally occurring molecule composed of three oxygen atoms. In the upper atmosphere O3 is an important gas that helps protect living organisms from harmful UV radiation. O3 is not typically found nearer to the ground except as a pollutant.

Where does it come from?

At ground level, O3 is primarily produced when sunlight reacts with other air pollutants like the nitrogen oxides (NOXs) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) found in car and truck exhausts and bushfire smoke. Because these chemical reactions require sunlight, ground level O3 levels are higher during the summer months.

How does it affect our health?

High O3 levels in the air can trigger breathing difficulties. O3 can worsen your symptoms if you have asthma, bronchitis or emphysema.

What is NO2?

NO2 is the chemical formula for nitrogen dioxide, a gas that forms part of the group of gases called the nitrogen oxides (NOXs).

Where does it come from?

The main sources of nitrogen dioxide are car and truck exhausts, coal-fired power stations, and industry.

How does it affect our health?

High levels of NO2 in the air can trigger breathing difficulties. NO2 can worsen your symptoms if you have asthma.

What is SO2?

The main sources of SO2 are diesel vehicle exhausts, coal-fired power stations and industry.

Where does it come from?

Sources can be emitted from either manmade or natural sources, or created by other pollutants.

How does it affect our health?

High levels of SO2 in the air can trigger breathing difficulties. SO2 can worsen your symptoms if you have asthma.

Air Quality

The Victorian Environmental Protection Authority uses two types of machines to monitor the quality of the air we breathe. These are called “standard” and “sensor” monitoring sites. Standard sites provide specific information about the concentrations of the different sizes of particulate matter and different gasses. Sensor sites are based on lower cost units and are deployed at more widely around Victoria. A limitation of the sensor sites is that they only provide general information about the amount of particulate matter in the air and do not correct for the effect of high humidity (for example, when it is foggy). If a sensor site isn’t available or is showing poor, very poor or extremely poor air quality, please double check this reading against the reading at a nearby standard site.

End User Licence Agreement (EULA)

The Melbourne Pollen Count (Service) provides users with pollen forecasts generated using real-world pollen count data collected from our statewide network of monitoring sites that are run by the School of BioSciences at the University of Melbourne, Australia (University).

The Service is provided for informational purposes only and is not intended to be used as a medical device or to diagnose, prevent, treat, mitigate, compensate or alleviate hay fever, asthma or any other respiratory ailment.

IF ASTHMA OR ANY OTHER RESPIRATORY SYMPTOMS ARE EXPERIENCED BY ANYONE USING THE SERVICE, SEEK MEDICAL ATTENTION FROM A TRAINED HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL WHO CAN PHYSICALLY EXAMINE THE INDIVIDUAL AND PROVIDE APPROPRIATE MEDICAL ADVICE, DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT.

In case of an emergency, call 000. If symptoms worsen or you have any medical concerns seek medical help.

THE SERVICE IS NOT A SUBSTITUTE FOR INDEPENDENT PROFESSIONAL ADVICE FROM YOUR QUALIFIED HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONAL.

The Service may be of assistance in the treatment of certain conditions; however the Service does not provide any form of or medical or psychological advice or prognosis. The Service is NOT a medical service. If you have any concerns regarding the use of the Service, please talk with your GP or other relevant health care provider.

Information and services are for information purposes only. By downloading and using the Service you:

  1. warrant that you are using the Service from within Australia;
  2. acknowledge that you will in no way whatsoever rely on any of its information, data, text, software, music, sound, photographs, graphics, video messages or other material (“Content”); and

surveyfaqs:
How do I score my symptoms?

Typical hay fever symptoms include a runny or blocked nose, sneezing and itchy eyes, nose, mouth or throat. Rate your symptoms on the five point scale above where 1 is no symptoms and 5 is severe symptoms. Use the guide below to help with your selection.

 
  No Symptoms
  Mild symptoms (my symptoms were slight and a nuisance)
  Slight (my symptoms were obvious but tolerable)
  Moderate (my symptoms were obvious, inconvenient but still tolerable)
  Severe (my symptoms were obvious and intolerable)
 

What are we doing with this data?

We want to track the average daily symptom score across the season and see how it compares to our daily pollen counts. Are symptoms worse on high grass pollen days than on days with low or moderate pollen counts? We aggregate the data and no individual information is retained. We also want to see if some areas of Melbourne are worse for hay fever than others. This will help us know where to site future pollen count stations as Melbourne continues to grow.

Questions about research ethics

For any complaints about the project, how its conducted or questions about participating in research in general, please contact us directly via e-mail.

Can I request that my survey scores be deleted?

All data submitted to us is de-identified before it is sent to our server. Unfortunately this means that once you make a submission we are not able to delete the data for a specific user.

Can I change or reset my survey settings?

Yes. By adjusting the settings below you can alter what data we receive when you fill out the survey.
 
Survey Participation:
 
Geolocation data:
Personal survey:

Show my survey scores
